reviewText:
Oh my god this is like poison. I played this game for free and I still feel ripped off.

If you want to play a card game online for free, there are tons of free Yu-Gi-Oh card games online. But I hear already,
'This is Magic, not Yu-Gi-Oh, Yu-Gi-Oh sucks, Magic is better blah blahgblahbshas'
That doesn't matter, what matters is that any of those free games have Thousands of cards to choose from, and this pitiful piece of trash has cards from two sets. Those other games also give you all the cards, so you can just play. I hear more complaints,
'But I want to get the cards, I don't want them handed to me at the begining, that way is for cheaters.'
Yeah, but at least it starts you with something! The starting cards in this game are a joke, and you cannot build a half decent deck out of them. Whatever you do build, will be on par or worse than the easy level ai, and with how you get cards (with coins, 6 or 8 at a time) and how you get coins (by winning, 10 at a time) you have to grind the easy bot before you can get the cards that synergize with each other enough to go onto the medium bot, so you can grind faster.

This wouldn't be too bad, maybe if the game wasn't so clunky and slow. Activating instants during the blocking phase is a chore, and during the damage step, physically impossible. Enevitabilities that you could just get over with quickly take what feel like eons when you have no cards to play and have to wait 20 seconds each turn to play a land and do nothing, while the opponent has a creature and is swinging at you for 2 until you die.
Trying to retaliate with instants that require timing is next to impossible, and the way the game sometimes auto taps lands can really screw over a plan, especially when the system to choose which lands to tap (in the rare times it does that) has no explination on how it works and results in pressing every button on the keyboard until it taps the lands that don't screw you over. The quests can give you an extra couple of coins, but its still a tedious grind to open random cards that may or may not help make a deck that synergizes better than this creature gets +1/+1 if you have an island."

No good cards to use at the start.
Boring grind to get cards that don't suck like a lung.
Clunky and slow gameplay with various greivences.

Don't touch this game.

reviewText: When Origins came out I would recommend this game because it was a grind game that actually had end game content. But now since all these sets are coming faster than I have time on my hand I cannot recommend this game. If you notice, I have a good amount of hours on this game and I have Origins,BFZ, and maybe 1/3 Of Gatewatch and SoI unlocked. I Was lvl 50 in origins and BfZ 1v1 rank and had 3000 coins which only unlocked me maybe 40% of SoI. This game really makes you feel overwhelmed and bogged down with money and lack of content. You could buy the packs if you wanted, but what would be the point of buying cards that will be flushed out and have no value unlike MTG:O. I'd recommend this game to players who are new to Magic, but they too may see the Grind too overbearing and the amount of cards that aren't synergistic to be confusing. I think I'd rather them have all cards unlocked from each set rather than 60-70% of the set of all cards of the past 3 sets. This isn't the only game I play and its hard to keep up with the cards since I use this as a casual sit back version of magic for me. The restraint on the game is just too High to maintain fun. 6 card booster packs for $1.99 when you can only unlock 1 mythical, 2 rares, 3 uncommons and 4 commons is just too restrictive. Though I wouldn't mind it if there were more Synergy amongst cards. But now there are 4 sets in the game at this update and you'd have to unlock 60-70% of one set to make a decent deck. I cannot unfortunately recommend this game. You are better off playing cockatrice if you are poor and MTG:O if you want to spend money.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I quite enjoy magic duels as a supplement to playing magic in real life.
It's free and its quite fun.
I didn't enjoy haveing to do so much in the way of tutorials as I've been playing magic for quite a while.
I know that earlier duels games asked you how much magic you've played at the start and adjust the tutorials from there, and I wish that this game had done so.

Everything about it is fun, the free to play elements come across as a bit nickle and dime-y but that's to be expected.
I wish they would allow for more options in how the game handles your turn, for example; there have been several times where I wanted to cast an instant on my turn and the game just skips past your turn.
I understand that you can pause the timer but this is a card game, my reflexes shouldn't have to be on point.

Ultimately I recommend it and give it a strong well earned 7/10

reviewText:
Magic Duels: Origins basically does the same mistakes as Duel of the Planeswalkers: It simplifies a game that lives of its complexity.

First for the pro:
- the game is free to play and such easily accesible for new players
- the tutorial is well made and most of the campaign is well balanced to introduce beginners to the game
- all the cards can be optained just by playing
- the game looks kind of nice and the deckbuilding-wizard is a great help to get started

Now the cons:
- the game simplifies many aspects of mtg, losing charm for advanced players
- the campaign is partially really unbalanced which can be really frustrating
- the cardpool is very limited at the moment and it takes ages to afford new boosters
- quests can only be completed with wizarded decks
- the controls are unintuitive

Conclusion:
Duels Origins is a good way for absolute beginners to get into magic, but it lacks way too many features and gameplay aspects to even be remotely interesting for advanced players. But since its free you can still have your fun with the game, playing some wanky cards you'd never play anywhere else.

reviewText:
This game is not necessarily a waste of your time.  Since it's free you should definitely play it just for the story mode.  Wizard/Stainless had one job.  Make a collectible card game(a 'CCG', if you want a TCG play cardboard Magic or MTGO).  They have failed, by definition of CCG.
You can't collect all the cards from the Origins set, and they've said that future expansions won't include all the cards either.  I did not expect to have every Magic card ever made, that would be far more work than I would consider viable.

I expected, wanted desperately, to play Magic: The Gathering.  This is not Magic, you can tell because it doesn't have the cards you need.  They even have the gall to put cards into the single player campaign (which is pretty fun and close to real MTG) but not into circulation.  So it is not laziness on their part, it was a choice.  It is not a choice I can respect.  It is a choice meant to, I don't know.  Presumably usher you toward 'real' Magic.

Dear WotC, if I had the time and patience and money to play MTG, I would already be playing MTG.

So ultimately I suppose I am not the target demographic and it does not satisfy my needs nor was it intended to do so.  However, assuming they are going for newbies, well, play the tutorials and campaign and find out if Magic is for you.  If you stay with this program longer, you will come up against limitations within a week.

reviewText:
Magic Duels suffers from similar issues to the previous games, in that the menus are slow to navigate and feature long unnecessary animations, requiring several clicks to reach certain parts of the menu system; skill quest menu, deckbuilding.

The cardplay is floaty and uninteractive, with intuitive motions such as flicking the card back into your hand still playing the card, viewing cards is performed using the mousewheel with a blurry animation lengthening the time to determine what is being played. Certain 'may' actions require a target to be selected even if you do not wish to perform the ability.

Interrupting gameplay to 'counter' or perform actions when you receive 'priority' features a very fast timer with inconcistent confirmation menus when the opponent plays cards.

Deckbuilding uses a carousel menu to display selected and available cards, meaning once you reach ~20 cards in the 60 card requirements it will be frustrating to determine what you are using. Selecting a card will initiate a brief loading period as it displays the next copy of the same card or puts a different card in the slot you last clicked on so there is a lot of waiting to add 4 copies of a card to the same deck. Also building a deck features a missing save button so you have to attempt to quit from the deckbuilding screen to alllow the software to remind you to save your deck changes.

Singleplayer gameplay is nothing more than trial and error to receive the opening hand that will win the game. While internet connectivity will ensure any other gamemode is at risk of wasting time.

The sound in the game is dominated by music that drowns out gameplay sounds to prevent the acknowledgment of the game making progress, and blurs the menus and gameplay together.

Wizards of the Coast do not hire competant programmers or have the managerial environment to allow large software deployments to occur for the complex game they have developed. Do not expect a digital version of Magic the Gathering to ever provide an experience you can be proud of. You do not have to pay for this version, so their incompetance cannot be rewarded.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There is a lot I have to say about this game so it will be easier if I make it a list:

- Good intro for new players to magic. Downside is that experiences players can't skip this and it's longer than it needs to be.
- It's relatively limited in the card selection. It's only one set of cards, so they make the currency grind way slower than it needs to be. In the F2P market you need to keep my attention and not giving out SOME currency for EVERY game type and giving out SOME reward for a loss is just wasting the player's time.
- There needs to be more options to speed up the animations and combat. There are some times that this is WAY too slow even after messing with the options.
- Obvious mobile port. There are too many extra things that can be done on a PC platform for a straight mobile to PC port to be acceptable.

reviewText:
Side Notes:
*I know it says I only have 0.3 hours on record but I've played a few more hours of this on Xbox One.*
*This is my first Magic the Gathering digital game. But I play the card game so I know my stuff.*

Pros:-Good tutorial for beginners.
-Nice deck building.
-Deck Helper works okay.
-They have all the standard cards and plan on just adding new cards into the game as they become available.
-Long Campaign with nice cutscene animations.
-Two headed giant mode (2v2 battle)

Cons:-No option to skip tutorial if you already know how to play.
-Terrible Gameplay (I'll discuss that more later).
-Campaign is boring and long. With no option to use your own decks.
-Gameplay is 'chunky' and frustrating and takes a long time to get used to.
-Limited Settings
-Bad value for your money (yes I know it's free).

Conclusion:Magic Duels has some nice new features that are nice but don't overrule the fact that it's just a bad game.
Absolutely horrific gameplay, that feels sluggish and slow and at the same time too quick and consfusing.
Campaign that has nice cutscenes but is long and repeditive, where your forced to use the game's decks.
Settings that annoy and did I mention all the server issues.

Don't clutter your harddrive with this 1.5GB download keep it clear and download a different free to play game. (Dota 2, Team Fortress 2, Soldier Front 2, Realm of the Mad God)

2/10

reviewText:
Four weak had elapsed since this game was realized in steam before it started work properly. After a short spell of being servers down, I must say I was most impressed with whole thing.
The first of all, we have a real freedom in deck-building. Anyone can manage your own deck using cards from pool that he/she already own. All cards are free to players, but, at first, you should collect them.

The way to expand your own collection is to by boosters which include three common, two uncommon and one rare or mythic rare card. There are six cards in each booster, and you never become overloaded with any card. The cap for commons is four cards, for uncommon - three, rare - two, mythic rare - only one. So, when you reach a maximum level for any specific card, you will never receive it again. Hence, sooner or later you collect whole set. Card booster you can buy with in-game currency, which you can receive just for playing the game or buy with real money. To buy at least one booster per day is not hard task.

Game have comprehensive tutorial and it would be easy to lean all basis for everyone. AI is sufficient to make a challenge, moreover, it is hard to run into the same deck when you playing against AI, because they are randomly customized at the beginning of each battle.

However, game have several cons. The first, the graphic in videos is really obsolete. I think, developers should have made a slideshow rather ugly video. The second, and the most essential problem is deficiency in communication with other players. There is no opportunity to send any message to other players or to invite them to be fiends. Lack of feedback is unpleasant, because chatting with an opponent is an important part of fun which we want to receive from board games.
Overall, this game deserve a high marks, and I believe it would be improved soon.
7/10

reviewText:
No, just no. This game runs an oversimplified version of the original card game while cutting corners. The original phases and steps of the turn are not in place for proper interactions with the cards, especially story mode cards. The game also lacks mouse key binding functions, something that I really wanted so that I could twitch my thumb to prevent the game from speeding out of control.

On top of those issues there is a bug where your enchantments fall off of your creatures when they are stolen, which is again devestating. I also want to know who designed the story mode decks. While each opponent you fight against has a flavorful themed deck, there is severe imbalance with the decks you are forced to pilot through out the mode. Seriously, I want to know which designer thought that having a mono-green morbid creatures deck going up against the second stage Lilianna was a good idea?

Even though this is free I highly recommend that you skip this game, ESPECIALLY if you are a fan of the physical game. Not a fan of the physical one? Still don't bother with the download, connection issues still plague the game as well as the quests failing to properly track progress.

reviewText:
This is a sad attempt from Wizards of the Coast to compete against Hearthstone. This is especially sad because I am not a big fan of Hearthstone.

While I had fun with Hearthstone at first, I soon realized that the game wasn't deep enough and the low card pool simply resulted in low variance and dull experience. It just simply didn't scratch the itch like Magic : the Gathering for me. I am not saying that Hearthstone is for noobs or something like that (Especially since I am pretty bad at the game.) the game couldn't simply compete with Magic which had years and years of releases and card pool of thousands.

For years, I was interested in trying digital versions of Magic the gathering. However, the horror stories kept me away from everything except Duels of the Planeswalkers 2014, which I still enjoy. There is a HUGE modding scene and I encourage everyone to check out.

When Magic Duels Origins was released, I was interested in trying it out.

After few hours of playing, I experienced the horror stories myself. The game crashes even though my computer CLEARLY surpasses the minimum requirment. Graphical glitches, server/connectivity issues, broken quest system, etc. I finally understood why Wizards of the Coast was infamous for producing technically incompetent products.

It is tragic that the game's fault isn't simply technically incompetent, but also flawed in game design as well. The card pool is extremely small. The game has roughly 250 cards in the game. Hearthstone, if I recall correctly, started out with more than 500 different cards and currently has almost 700 cards. If you read above, I quit Hearthstone due to lack of variance. This game is utter joke which fails to understand the strength of Magic the Gathering card game. What is the point of allowing players to design their own decks if you are not going to give them any cards to play with!?

Wizards need to realize that people are willing to pay money for solid, technically competent, fun, digital Magic product. Why won't Wizards take my money? I simply don't know.

reviewText:
Update (8/20/15):

Finally the game worked and I got a chance to play. My review is still a non-recommend for this game. I just played the story mode for a few hours... Please save yourself the pain. The enemy has finished decks and you have unfinished non-counters to their deck styles... yet you can not pick your own deck. So they force you to be gimped while their npc is O.P. The second level of the story mode is more about getting absolutely lucky with your draws while the enemy get highly unlucky... so get ready to start your matches by chosing a new hand and when it penalizes you by not giving you 7 cards accept the hand and restart duel. I had a blue deck that was focused on making the enemy discard cards... but the deck seems to have at most 6 cards that have anything to do with discarding cards... I really do not feel like rambling and fully explaining. All i can say is the game just for me was not fun at all. I love magic and have played it for many years. This will not be something I play. It just seems like the devs are either way off base with the customers or they are way too elitest in the set up of the game. either way when it comes to me and probably a majority of the demographic I come from I can play magic in real life and from many other games forms.

BTW your game does not play full screen windowed so i enjoy greatly not being able to play this absolute headache of a game fullscreen with part of the bottom of the picture cut off when using 1920x1080.

I will review what I experienced. I was excited about the change to play a Magic: The Gathering game... I added the game to my library, Loaded it up, and got a beatiful view of the games Magic symbol. The screen then went black for about 20 seconds. With a woosh I was brought back into the light from the black screen to my normal desktop. In a confusion I looked around the screen trying to figure out what had happened... Oh wait what is that?" I wondered. The game is opened and shows its symbol at my botton screen taskbar. I click it thinking it will open the game. "Oh wow the screen went black... the game is opening! WooHoo!" I said with happiness. To my surprise about 20 seconds later yet again the black screen goes away and brings me back to my normal desktop. This journey of Deja Vu was done multiple times and attempted over longer than needed periods of time. The happiness faded and now all I have to say is I do not recommend this game. It does not even look like anyone really replies to forum posts about this game breaking issue. I do not like it when a company does not reply especially on issues such as this. Sooo I do not recommend this game and if the way the company is handleing this issue shows anything I do not recommend this company. Sorry
date: but not sorry. Maybe if you fix your game in a timely manner I will be happy to play it and change my review to a review about the actual game and not your unplayable game."

reviewText: I've played Magic for over 20 years, and I really really hoped this would transfer all the fun and interactivity of the game into a reliable computer client, since MTGO is a buggy eyesore. While Duels certainly looks cleaner than MTGO and isn't full of rude people, the support it seems to be getting from its publisher is pretty pathetic. Constant delays, incomplete sets, poor communication from the developers, no apparent mechanism to lodge bug reports or file comlaints... given that this barely feels like more than a reskin of the previous annual computer releases, the overal product is quite dissapointing. It's easy enough to play and they've increased payouts significantly lately, presumably to retain what players haven't been scared off yet, but given the competition games like Hearthstone provide these days, the most venerable CCG could--and should--have done way better.

reviewText: I was so excited for this game and I was severely disapointed. It has the potential to be an ok game but its awful at the moment. I've been playing Magic for 8 years. There was no need for me to go through the tutorial, yet I was forced to. There is no way to skip it. And the tutorial continues throughout the story mode. It was slow and bothersome. I was also having problems with the graphics. The textures worked fine throughout the tutorial stages but as soon as I got to a level where there was not one, background under the cards became gridded and grey and would flicker every time the mouse would move. I adjusted the graphics as much as the game would allow, which was much. It has an option to turn graphics from low to high and change resolution, but there were no ther graphics options. My computer can run most other games so I was highly surprised to be having such issues with a card game of all things. I would not recommend this game to anyone. Its terrible in its current state. A lot of work needs to be done before I will even consider giving it a second shot.

reviewText: This game seemed so promising - I won't go over all the problems with connectivity and all that trash, you can scroll down and read a bit that other people have already said a thousand times over. What I will say, though, is that when I logged back in after all the connectivity issues, I suddenly had none of my hard earned coins from playing through those terrible campaigns, and getting to customer service was such a massive pain that I just gave up entirely.\nNot only that, but it's kindof uncanny how every time I'm about to win a duel, my opponent has a connection failure, which prevents that win from counting towards my quest. Thanks, Stainless!\nIt's really disappointing how messed up this game is; it was really, really promising, but it's just so poorly designed. At this point I'm just going to be hoping for a patch that makes this game into something playable.

reviewText: This game show potential. I enjoyed some of it, for example, the ability to earn cards, and build your own decks to fight each other with the advanced deck builder. I think it is a step in the right direction. It also has some design flaws, and some bugs. The bugs might get fixed, the design flaws probably never will. They have an archetype deck builder. I assume the original purpose was to help beginners, but it actually just blows. There is no flexibility, no way to customize it if you see a balance issue with it as far as lands or some other abitrary limits. That will never be fixed. I say this because actual bug fixes are so slow, that there is no way in gods name they would actually change their jenky little formulas. There are other examples, of poor design, but you will see it if you give it a try. And let's face it, this is the ugly step child of magic, and a half-♥♥♥♥♥ foray into competing with hearthstone

reviewText:
I've been playing Hearthstone for the last year or so because there was no MTG equivalent, a F2P card game where you can build your own decks and just play a quick game of MTG when there's no friends nearby. When I heard Duels was coming out, I figured i'd gotten my wish.

Unfortunately, I did not.

To begin, the gameplay is fine. It's tried-and-true MTG gameplay and it's compeltely fine. The problems are with all the 'little' things; the UI is atrocious and just doesn't control well (what bonehead thought that scrolling to zoom in on a card was a good idea?!), it moves way too slowly, the player-centric camera makes it difficult to see you opponent's board, and the deck builder is just unintuitive and useless.

If this gets some fixes, it'll be worth another look. But for now, it's just a waste of time. I've played MTG since Onslaught, but they haven't won me over digitally yet. I'll stick to Hearthstone and playing casual EDH, thanks.

reviewText:
Magic with a Hearthstone UI, minus the charm and the part where the actual gameplay is suited to such a UI. It may be useful for teaching someone the basics of Magic, but for veterans it's probably not worth the download time.

Default settings will pick the damage distribution for you when you block with multiple creatures, and won't let you use instants and abilities after blockers are assigned (but before damage is dealt). It's horrible, especially in story mode decks that absolutely require doing this to play effectively (and the AI does it even if you can't).

This might be because of the (on by default) Auto Resolution setting, which is described as Automatically resolve effects of many spells and abilities". I guess combat damage is a "spell or ability" now.

The short countdown timer on phases is terrible. You'll either be forced to wait around on phases you can't do anything on
date: or you'll be suddenly shoved off to the next phase because you didn't mash the "pause timer" button in the 5 seconds or so from when the phase started. Trying to squeeze in an instant or ability in the opponent's End Phase? Nope
recommended: it's your main phase now! Stop looking at your cards for so long
voteText: the only way to grow your collection beyond the starter set is through random boosters (there's just one kind of booster in the entire game; the "Store" just lets you buy 1 pack
helpfulPercent: 2 packs
votesHelpful: 4 packs
votesTotal: etc...) and you can't really make a decent deck in most of the deck wizard archetypes with the starting collection they give you.\n\nIt can be fun to dabble in the Story mode for solo play with prebuilt decks (when the terrible phase progression system doesn't cost you the match)
votesFunny: but for actual deckbuilding and multiplayer
commentsCount: just pick up Magic The Gathering Online. It's not pretty and it's a little less streamlined

reviewText:
Pretty straightfoward MtG card game but so many glitches and bugs still. Rewards works... well sometimes but not completely and there is a limit but you can't know when. I do not know what was the goal of that game but I'm pretty sure it hasn't been achieved yet...

Pros:
- Magic the Gathering in Free-to-Play form. (No pay-to-win but patience is required)
- Smooth game flow, animations, and sound effects. (a bit tight on the instant" side)
- I like that the story is intertwined with the game
date:
even if it is a short storyline it give cards flavor text more meaning. (I always wanted to read all the novels from MtG but they are hard to get a hand on)

Cons:
- Some mechanics don't work well (or don't work at all)
- Connection issues (specially in multiplayer duels)
- Reward system not true to what is displayed (often coins doesn't get added unless you restart the game)
- Can't get most rewards with your own deck builds (need a flagged deck created by wierd semi-auto builder)
- Duels simply has no real outlet for competitive play.
- The simulated perspective of the game board need a zoom function or something
recommended:
cards are already hard enough to read/target when the board gets cluttered. (even truer when doing a double-headed giant)

I don't recommend it yet unless you're okay with ALOT of swearing (note: there is no in-game chatting function so it will come from your own end).

Waiting for it to be fixed..."

reviewText: I have never once been able to connect to the game. It has been out for almost a full three months. I have never once connected to the server. I can do nothing in the game and have never once been able to do anything that is not the damned tutorial. This problem does not exist on the consoles or the mobile version, as I have friends who play on both, but on the PC I can not play the game. This is so aggrevating as a huge fan of Magic who has been playing for over 5 years, both in physical cards and in digital versions, to be completely unable to do anything beyond the first mission. I would suggest the game, as the mechanics appear to be all there and this appears to be a very good itteration of the game and training tool for new players but I have no way of knowing that BECAUSE I CAN'T PLAY THE DAMN GAME THREE MONTHS AFTER RELEASE! FIX YOUR GAME WOTC!

reviewText:
- Slower than previous iterations - the feel of the gameplay -- artificially feels slowed down
- Removed the lobby since DoTP 14, I don't know why but it's very frustrating
- Too many clicks to changes decks and restart a match, especially in 2HG
- Bug, bugs and more bugs. Often crashing, can't build some decks (Elf), can't play if Magic is offline, which is a lot of the time
- It's F2P, and while i'm not a fan of that model I could have looked past it, but this has too many bugs.

I've gone back to 12, 13 and 14. those are more fun IMO. 14 can be modded to include the decks from 12 and 13 with a quick internet search.

reviewText: My experience with Magic Duels can be summed in two words, but before I do allow me to tell you a story. In those halcyon days of 1996, just before Alliances was released, I played Magic for the first time. It wasn't my first time seeing the game, but the first time I actually bothered to learn the game and play it. Not long after that, I started playing in tournaments, and not long after winning those local tournaments. I made friends, I made enemies, and my life was linked inextricably with characters both colorful and shady. Magic: The Gathering has since devolved into a rich man's game, and I'm no rich man. Now, my sole connection to the game is through Magic Workstation and the occasional prerelease. I kid you not when I tell you in my time playing this game, I've come across every kind of person from criminals to porn stars and FATAL ERROR

reviewText: I was so excited for this game and I was severely disapointed. It has the potential to be an ok game but its awful at the moment. I've been playing Magic for 8 years. There was no need for me to go through the tutorial, yet I was forced to. There is no way to skip it. And the tutorial continues throughout the story mode. It was slow and bothersome. I was also having problems with the graphics. The textures worked fine throughout the tutorial stages but as soon as I got to a level where there was not one, background under the cards became gridded and grey and would flicker every time the mouse would move. I adjusted the graphics as much as the game would allow, which was much. It has an option to turn graphics from low to high and change resolution, but there were no ther graphics options. My computer can run most other games so I was highly surprised to be having such issues with a card game of all things. I would not recommend this game to anyone. Its terrible in its current state. A lot of work needs to be done before I will even consider giving it a second shot.

reviewText: This game seemed so promising - I won't go over all the problems with connectivity and all that trash, you can scroll down and read a bit that other people have already said a thousand times over. What I will say, though, is that when I logged back in after all the connectivity issues, I suddenly had none of my hard earned coins from playing through those terrible campaigns, and getting to customer service was such a massive pain that I just gave up entirely.\nNot only that, but it's kindof uncanny how every time I'm about to win a duel, my opponent has a connection failure, which prevents that win from counting towards my quest. Thanks, Stainless!\nIt's really disappointing how messed up this game is; it was really, really promising, but it's just so poorly designed. At this point I'm just going to be hoping for a patch that makes this game into something playable.

date: the Deck Dictator actually forbids you from making any deviations from its suggested cards
recommended: even when you've finished the deck and want to make some changes to it. It's good only for learning how many lands you should put in a deck.\n\nStory Mode? As confusing and disconnected as the whole affair was
hoursPlayed: what irked me the most was the true source of the bosses' difficulty; your own deck. Not only are there many bosses whose decks are built perfectly for countering yours (Not the final bosses of the campaigns

want to play sometime during the afternoon? Maybe late morning? Impossible!

reviewText:
4 out of 10, and it decreases the more you play it.

Ok, so time for a review for Migic Duels Origins. My first impression of the game was that it looked great, very catchy to the eye, so I decided to give it a try. I am not a Magic the Gathering player, so the tutorial was really detailed and fun in my opinion. I got hooked... I played it for a while, grinded a little for coins, got some nice cards eventually, and made a decent white-green elf deck. Sounds great right? Well it was for some time, but eventually some serious flaws with game became obvious to me.

First of all, grinding for coins kills a lot of the potential this game could have. Each victory against another player only rewards you 20 coins from the 150 required to buy just 1 booster pack, and each booster pack only gives you six cards (mostly common or boring rare cards unless you are very lucky). When you star playing the game, you get gold from tutorial quests and story mode. There are 5 campaigns on story mode with 5 missions each, and if you complete one the game rewards you with 150 gold (a booster). This is good and all, but you can complete all of this in a single all nighter. Which brings me to the last way in which players can earn gold in-game: Daily and weekly quests which can give you 20-40 coins depending on their difficulty and your luck.

Yes, you can buy coins and not grind  at all, but I am adamant against  it at the momment,I don't know if want to be playing this in the future yet.  Months from now I might completely forget about it, so why spend money on a game that was just released and I am not so convinced about its play value yet? So I played and tested it out a little to see if it is worthy of the time and money I usually spend on games that I really love to play. My conclusion on this matter was: No, or perhaps not yet. Stainless games and wizard of the coast need to improve 3 fatal flaws in order for me to recommend this game:

1) Most quests I mentioned before can only be completed with decks created through the deck wizard feature. For those of you who do not know anything about this game yet, you can create your decks in two manners: Full Deck Builder, a beautifully crafted feature that allows you to freely configure your deck while you can sort and filter your card collection, and Deck Wizard, a godamn-awful-restricting feature that I can't ever imagine wanting to use it! So why make it so that you require to use this feature in order to complete the archetype decks quests? I cannot complete quests with my carefully crafted green and white deck, I have to use the green and white deck recommended by the awful deck wizard feature. This wouldn't be so horrible if there werent so many archetype quests, but I got three of them in a row (and remember you only get 1 daily). You can still complete these quests if you play against the easy AI, but it is just awful to create a deck to use twice for a quest and disregarding it afterwards.

2) The game needs to be more rewarding and varied, it is awful to have to win 8 battles (sometimes against people who have paid real money to buy cards which is okay but admitedly harder) to buy a single pack which will likely have cards that you won't use (either because you don't like them or they simply don't synergize with the cards you already have). Yeah, the quests help, but after you complete all campaigns and tutorials it all feels so slow... Two Headed Dragon, an awesome game mode which let players go on 2 vs 2 matches doesn't give you anything when you win... It is the only alternate game mode and it is not rewarding to play it, fun at times, but doesn't help me improve my collection at all.

3) The bugs and glitches... I know that it is new a game and that they already admitted on their twitter page that they are still working on these, but the game gets stuck from time to time. Yes, this third point is understandable in my opinion, they didn't have a beta testing as far as I know, but it is an issue. I had games as good as won when for some reason it doesn't let me play my cards and gets stuck, this glitch happened twice and has made me concede games when I am winning (The other opponent had 2 of health and no monsters at the beginning of my turn ugh). Also, game sometimes gets stuck on the loading screen, I had to restart my laptop once, As I said, it is a new game so I try to be patient; nonetheless, it is still a flaw that needs to be pointed out  until it is solved.

As it is, this game is just a tutorial for new players and a clever commercial for the physical and the online complete version of this trading card game. Not rewarding enough and slow paced at times. It feels like the more you play it, the less enjoyable it is. They need to do something drastical if they mean to flip that curve.

reviewText:
Well, I'm pretty addicted to mtg, so I was enjoying my time playing despite the crashes, bugs and disconnects.  But I'm going to have to find a new game for my relaxation time. The straw that broke the camel's back: I win game, but continue gives me a black screen hang.

I reboot my computer (as this is what I end up having to do eventually each time this happens since force quit doesn't seem to work, and the game leaves my laptop wonky if I can even get rid of the duels process).

When I restart duels, it tells me that there is a mismatch in my local and cloud saved decks, choose one and it will delete the other. No clue what the difference was, so I assume its a case of the cloud save not being up to date and choose local. Oops, my bad.

Apparently the difference was the local had NO DECKS. Now all 11 of my custom decks are gone. The 'customer service' website requires a wizards account login, and my system is lagging to hell because the game is still running, and I'm holding on to my temper by a thread.

To the devs who omitted any safeguards from the process of deleting all your decks: thanks, you guys! Maybe I'll get some work done now that I've deleted the desktop icon!

To other users:
- lots of frustration
- seems like not as much mana screw as in previous games (yay?)
- horribly annoying default gameplay options (most correctable in gameplay options)
- still easy to miss your chance to respond to a spell or stop the timer (how hard would it be to let us check a box so we could always stop at opponent's end of turn?)
- very buggy, frequent crashes, black screen hangs and disconnects
- runs terribly on my crummy laptop (though most steam games are fine)
- deckbuilder was pretty fun - but not so fun I want to recreate all my decks... :(

I give it a 4/10.

reviewText:
I've been playing Hearthstone for the last year or so because there was no MTG equivalent, a F2P card game where you can build your own decks and just play a quick game of MTG when there's no friends nearby. When I heard Duels was coming out, I figured i'd gotten my wish.

Unfortunately, I did not.

To begin, the gameplay is fine. It's tried-and-true MTG gameplay and it's compeltely fine. The problems are with all the 'little' things; the UI is atrocious and just doesn't control well (what bonehead thought that scrolling to zoom in on a card was a good idea?!), it moves way too slowly, the player-centric camera makes it difficult to see you opponent's board, and the deck builder is just unintuitive and useless.

If this gets some fixes, it'll be worth another look. But for now, it's just a waste of time. I've played MTG since Onslaught, but they haven't won me over digitally yet. I'll stick to Hearthstone and playing casual EDH, thanks.

reviewText:
Magic with a Hearthstone UI, minus the charm and the part where the actual gameplay is suited to such a UI. It may be useful for teaching someone the basics of Magic, but for veterans it's probably not worth the download time.

Default settings will pick the damage distribution for you when you block with multiple creatures, and won't let you use instants and abilities after blockers are assigned (but before damage is dealt). It's horrible, especially in story mode decks that absolutely require doing this to play effectively (and the AI does it even if you can't).

This might be because of the (on by default) Auto Resolution setting, which is described as Automatically resolve effects of many spells and abilities". I guess combat damage is a "spell or ability" now.

The short countdown timer on phases is terrible. You'll either be forced to wait around on phases you can't do anything on
date: or you'll be suddenly shoved off to the next phase because you didn't mash the "pause timer" button in the 5 seconds or so from when the phase started. Trying to squeeze in an instant or ability in the opponent's End Phase? Nope
recommended: it's your main phase now! Stop looking at your cards for so long

reviewText:
It's a real shame Wizards can't deliver on MtG because it's such a fun game to play.

The campaing is rather short but fun. The tell short stories about the popular planeswalkers gradually evolving their decks. While this is a step back from previous duels games it's still nice to play. The short tutorial turns are a nice way of introducing basic mechanics to new players. Overall the gameplay hasn't changed much since the previous installement and is pretty well polished. It's fast and smooth once you get used to some gimmicks. The introduction of unlimited deckbuilding brings us closer to magic proper although the card pool feels rather small, but that will change with time.

So why the negative review? Well:
* The interface is basically designed for tablets. The player has to scroll through rows of cards, icons, etc with 'swiping' moves to do anything. It's tedious and irritating and does not suit mouse controls.
* The multiplayer is kinda meh, no interactions (ways to congratulate or taunt your oponent) makes the experience dull. To top it off there seems to be no penalty for idling which is often exploited by oponents. Also when an oponent ragequits the AI steps in and you still have to finish the game.
* Some campaign missions basically require you to restart until you get a decent hand because they're practically unbeatable otherwise. Not a big pain, but still looks like a balancing issue.
* But the worst offender is the deckbuilder. No way to search your freaking library in any meaningfull way! What the hell? It's so frustrating to build a deck when all you get are color and cost filters. If you want to find anything you have to scroll through rows of cards with 'swiping' moves. There's also no way to see your whole deck at once which is ♥♥♥♥ if youre trying to build anything with some sort of synergy. It looks like no thought was put into designing any of it which is inexcusable in a pc game, and frankly a game where deckbuilding is the most fun. 0/10

To sum it up, the game shows potential but until someone steps in and fixins the UI and multiplayer issues you're better off playing hearthstone.

reviewText:
Magic the Gathering has been a game I've enjoyed for over 15 years and the DoTP series has been (except for last year) one I've quite enjoyed despite its shortcomings. I've looked forward to what the developer could do with the next iteration.

Well, this developer has done a poor job. As others have mentioned the series has regressed, losing features. The series is obviously mimicking Hearthstone but doing a bad job of it.

My main gripes:

15g per win (20g vs online opponent) and 150g to buy a booster pack of only 6 cards. No discount for buying packs in bulk. Plus a weak card pool (not just the rares, but even more importantly the commons and uncommons) for every archetype (aggro, midrange, control, ramp, combo). This means a long and rather uninteresting grind.

A frustrating beginner experience because of the above. Its not much fun to use a very limited, weak, and uninteresting pool of cards against more interesting decks played by the AI.

The AI has not improved in this series for over four years. It doesn't seem to have been worked on.

Removed different gameplay modes and challenges from the campaign.

Can't get gold from 2 headed giant games? So you put in a feature and penalize players who enjoy that feature. Again, these players already have to slowly grind for gold. How does that make sense?

Can't save account/game data across platforms. Their excuse for this was lame. Hearthstone can do it and its been out for a while. Who cares if its out on iPhone, iPad, Steam, and console if you have to create an account for each one? Discourages players from long term play and investing $$ in the game for gold and packs. This is a major, major flaw.

Can play a 30-40 minute game against an online opponent, right before winning the opp quits/disconnects and you lose connection to the game and will not gain any gold for the win. This just happened to me. The payout is bad enough without this disconnects.

Solutions:

Increase the amount of gold per win to 25g.

Quests should give at least 75g each. These massive worldwide coop quests should be even more. A worldwide quest today has a 40g reward. Not even 1/3 of a pack.

Increase booster packs to AT LEAST 8 cards  per pack, but preferably 9-10.

Do whatever coding you have to do to make it cross platform compatible.

Hire a new developer.

Give free packs to all customers for all the grief with the servers and all these letdowns. This costs you no money but makes the customer base feel listened to and happy. Happy and loyal customers is a good thing.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have been playing Magic: The Gathering for the better part of 20 years.  I play casual Magic in real life very often, I am familiar with all the rules to a high degree and have played approximately 1000 online matches of the Duels of The Planeswalker games in years past.

Although it had some weird drawbacks--namely not being able to remove any unlocked cards from your deck--the first iteration of this game was awesome.  It got me back into the game: here was something that was easy to play, had a good mix of different card and deck types, and was just a really streamlined, accessible way to play casual M:tG games without having to get a group together and worry about deck balance.

The next two (or three, I forget how many now) were similarly excellent.  Rudimentary deck editing allowed seasoned players much greater control over how they played, and was a much more managable way for new players to learn the ins and outs of what makes or breaks a deck.

Magic 2015 and this new Duels have just taken huge strides backwards.  Forcing players to build their own decks without actually providing any information on why and how the old archetypes were constructed makes the gap between pros and newbs that much wider, and makes for a much more narrow metagame than previous years.  Add in the lack of extra modes, the inability to skip a patronizingly hand-holding tutorial for advanced players, and a cap on how much you can progress in the game ON YOUR OWN TIME to further encourage spending extra money on the game, and in my opinion you have the worst game Stainless has put out yet.

Obviously I haven't played it very much, and I may go back and slog through the intros to sink my teeth in a little deeper, but this game is exactly what no one was asking for.

The ones who just don't get it are the ones who scream the loudest."  I've heard WotC say players have been clamoring for open-ended deck editing for years

reviewText:
It's a real shame Wizards can't deliver on MtG because it's such a fun game to play.

The campaing is rather short but fun. The tell short stories about the popular planeswalkers gradually evolving their decks. While this is a step back from previous duels games it's still nice to play. The short tutorial turns are a nice way of introducing basic mechanics to new players. Overall the gameplay hasn't changed much since the previous installement and is pretty well polished. It's fast and smooth once you get used to some gimmicks. The introduction of unlimited deckbuilding brings us closer to magic proper although the card pool feels rather small, but that will change with time.

So why the negative review? Well:
* The interface is basically designed for tablets. The player has to scroll through rows of cards, icons, etc with 'swiping' moves to do anything. It's tedious and irritating and does not suit mouse controls.
* The multiplayer is kinda meh, no interactions (ways to congratulate or taunt your oponent) makes the experience dull. To top it off there seems to be no penalty for idling which is often exploited by oponents. Also when an oponent ragequits the AI steps in and you still have to finish the game.
* Some campaign missions basically require you to restart until you get a decent hand because they're practically unbeatable otherwise. Not a big pain, but still looks like a balancing issue.
* But the worst offender is the deckbuilder. No way to search your freaking library in any meaningfull way! What the hell? It's so frustrating to build a deck when all you get are color and cost filters. If you want to find anything you have to scroll through rows of cards with 'swiping' moves. There's also no way to see your whole deck at once which is ♥♥♥♥ if youre trying to build anything with some sort of synergy. It looks like no thought was put into designing any of it which is inexcusable in a pc game, and frankly a game where deckbuilding is the most fun. 0/10

To sum it up, the game shows potential but until someone steps in and fixins the UI and multiplayer issues you're better off playing hearthstone.
